definitions: arrange objects in a neat pile one on top of another
accumulate or build up gradually over a period of time
arrange something dishonestly to gain an unfair advantage
examples: She carefully stacked the books on the library shelf
The workers stacked boxes in the warehouse all morning
Evidence continues to stack against the suspected criminal defendant
The bills keep stacking up on my kitchen counter
They stacked the committee with their own political supporters
The casino suspected someone had stacked the deck deliberately

definitions: provide an organization or business with necessary workers or personnel
work as a member of staff in a particular organization
examples: The hospital struggles to staff the emergency department adequately
They plan to staff the new office with local employees
She staffed at the university library for three years
Many volunteers staff the information desk during tourist season

definitions: attend a social event without bringing a romantic partner or date
watch or spy on someone secretly for intelligence gathering purposes
examples: He decided to stag the wedding rather than find a date
Several friends stagged the party together last Saturday night
The detective stagged the suspect's house for several weeks
Intelligence agents stagged the meeting from across the street

definitions: present a theatrical performance or play for an audience
organize and present an event or situation for public attention
progress through planned phases or stages of development systematically
examples: The drama club will stage Shakespeare's Hamlet next month
They staged the musical at the historic downtown theater
Protesters staged a demonstration outside the government building yesterday
The company staged an elaborate product launch event downtown
The disease stages through four distinct phases before remission
They staged the home renovations over several months carefully

definitions: walk or move unsteadily as if about to fall from weakness
shock or deeply astonish someone with surprising or overwhelming information
arrange events or objects at different times or positions to avoid overlap
examples: The injured player staggered off the field holding his head
He staggered home after drinking too much at the party
The final cost estimate staggered everyone at the board meeting
News of the scandal staggered the entire local community yesterday
They staggered employee lunch breaks to reduce cafeteria crowding
The airline staggers flight departures to minimize runway congestion

definitions: mark or discolor something with a substance that is difficult to remove
damage or tarnish someone's reputation or character with shameful actions
examples: Red wine stained the white tablecloth during dinner last night
Grass stains marked his jeans after playing football outside
The corruption scandal stained his political career beyond repair
These accusations could stain the company's reputation for years

definitions: risk money or something valuable on the outcome of an event
mark an area or boundary with wooden posts driven into the ground
assert one's claim or right to something valuable or important
examples: He staked his entire savings on the new business venture
Professional gamblers rarely stake more than they can afford
Surveyors staked the property boundaries before construction began yesterday
They staked the garden plot with wooden posts and string
Mining companies staked claims throughout the mountain region historically
She staked her claim to the family inheritance early

definitions: become no longer fresh or pleasant through age or lack of air
examples: The bread will stale quickly if left unwrapped overnight
Chips stale within hours once the bag is opened

definitions: bring to a position where no progress can be made by either side
examples: The negotiations stalemated after both sides refused to compromise
The chess match stalemated when neither player could force checkmate

definitions: pursue prey or quarry stealthily by following quietly and carefully
follow or harass someone persistently and obsessively causing fear or distress
walk in a stiff, proud, or angry manner with measured steps
examples: The lion stalked the antelope through tall grass patiently
Hunters stalked deer through the forest for several hours
The celebrity filed charges against fans who stalked her home
He stalked his ex-girlfriend on social media for months
She stalked out of the meeting after the heated argument
The angry customer stalked away from the service counter

definitions: cause an engine or vehicle to stop running suddenly and unintentionally
use delaying tactics to postpone or avoid making a decision or taking action
put or keep an animal in a stall or stable compartment
examples: The car stalled at the traffic light during rush hour
New drivers often stall manual transmission vehicles while learning
Politicians stalled the vote until they secured more support
Stop stalling and give us your answer about the proposal
Farmers stall their horses in the barn during winter storms
They stalled the cattle before the veterinary inspection began

definitions: bring down one's foot heavily and forcefully on the ground or surface
mark or impress a pattern or seal on a surface using a tool
suppress or eliminate something completely and forcefully from existence
examples: The child stamped her feet angrily during the temper tantrum
Horses stamped nervously in their stalls before the storm
Officials stamp passports at international border crossing checkpoints daily
The company stamps its logo on every product manufactured
The government vowed to stamp out corruption in public offices
Firefighters worked tirelessly to stamp out the forest blaze

definitions: rush wildly in a sudden mass panic often causing danger or damage
examples: The cattle stampeded when lightning struck near the pasture
Shoppers stampeded toward the doors during the sale event

definitions: be in or rise to an upright position on one's feet
tolerate or endure something unpleasant without giving up or complaining
remain valid, unchanged, or in effect despite challenges or time passing
take up a position to defend or support a particular principle or belief
examples: Please stand when the judge enters the courtroom today
She stood at the window watching the rain fall
I cannot stand the noise from the construction site anymore
How can you stand working such long hours every day?
The court's original decision stands despite multiple appeals filed
Our offer stands until the end of this month only
We must stand against injustice wherever we encounter it
She stands firmly behind her decision to resign yesterday

definitions: make things conform to a standard or uniform set of specifications or criteria
examples: The company standardised its manufacturing processes across all factories
Schools need to standardise their testing procedures for fairness

definitions: make things conform to a standard or uniform set of specifications or criteria
examples: The company standardized its manufacturing processes across all factories
Schools need to standardize their testing procedures for fairness

definitions: fasten or attach papers or materials together using small metal fasteners
examples: Please staple these documents together before filing them away
The teacher stapled the assignment sheets to the syllabus

definitions: feature as the leading performer or main attraction in a performance or production
mark something with a star symbol or asterisk to indicate importance or special attention
examples: She will star in the new Broadway musical next season
The film stars several Academy Award winning actors together
Teachers star the most important homework problems for students
The menu stars dishes that are chef's special recommendations

definitions: turn or steer a ship or aircraft to the right side when facing forward
examples: The captain ordered the crew to starboard immediately to avoid collision
Pilots starboard when approaching the runway from the north

definitions: stiffen fabric or clothing with starch solution to make it crisp and formal
examples: The laundry service starches dress shirts for business professionals
My grandmother always starched the tablecloths before holiday dinners

definitions: look fixedly at something or someone with eyes wide open for a long time
examples: Children often stare at strangers out of innocent curiosity
She stared at the painting trying to understand its meaning

definitions: begin doing something or come into being from a particular point
cause something to begin operating or functioning from an initial state
establish or found a new business, organization, or venture from nothing
make a sudden involuntary movement from surprise, fear, or shock
examples: The meeting will start at nine o'clock tomorrow morning
She started learning Spanish when she moved to Madrid
Can you start the car while I grab my bag?
The supervisor started the assembly line after the break
They started their own consulting company after leaving corporate jobs
She started a nonprofit organization to help homeless veterans
The loud noise made everyone start in their seats suddenly
He started when someone tapped his shoulder unexpectedly yesterday

definitions: cause someone to feel sudden shock or alarm by an unexpected event or sound
examples: The sudden thunder startled the sleeping baby awake last night
Don't startle me like that when I'm concentrating deeply

definitions: suffer or die from extreme hunger and lack of food over time
deprive someone or something of necessary resources or attention deliberately
examples: Millions of people starve in regions affected by severe drought
The lost hikers nearly starved before rescue teams found them
The government starved the rebellion of funds and support effectively
Don't starve your plants of water during the summer months

definitions: store or hide something valuable in a secret place for safekeeping or future use
examples: She stashed emergency cash in various places around the house
Drug dealers often stash their supplies in abandoned buildings

definitions: express something clearly and definitely in spoken or written words
specify formally or officially requirements, terms, or conditions in documentation
examples: Please state your name and address for the court record
The witness stated that she saw the accident happen clearly
The contract clearly states all payment terms and conditions explicitly
The law states that minors cannot purchase alcoholic beverages

definitions: assign someone to a particular place or position for duty or a specific purpose
examples: The army stationed troops along the contested border permanently
Security guards were stationed at every entrance during the event

definitions: stop or restrict the flow of blood or other liquid from a wound or opening
examples: The paramedic used pressure to staunch the bleeding quickly
Emergency measures were taken to staunch the financial losses

definitions: ward off or delay something bad or dangerous from happening for a period
examples: The company borrowed money to stave off bankruptcy temporarily
Taking vitamins might help stave off winter colds effectively

definitions: remain in the same place without moving or leaving for a period
continue to be in a particular state or condition without changing
live somewhere temporarily as a guest or visitor for a period
postpone or delay a judicial decision or legal proceeding temporarily
examples: Please stay here while I go check on the situation
The dog stayed by his owner's side all night long
The weather stayed sunny throughout our entire vacation fortunately
She stayed calm despite the chaos surrounding the emergency
We stayed at a lovely hotel during our Paris vacation
My cousin stayed with us for two weeks last summer
The judge stayed the execution pending further evidence review
The court stayed its decision until all appeals concluded

definitions: make or hold something firm, stable, and controlled without shaking or wavering
become stable, regular, or constant after a period of fluctuation or uncertainty
examples: She steadied the ladder while he climbed to the roof
The nurse steadied his hand before giving the injection
Stock prices steadied after the initial market panic subsided
His breathing steadied once the medication took full effect

definitions: take another person's property without permission or legal right and without intending to return it
move somewhere quietly or secretly without being noticed by others
examples: Someone stole my bicycle from the garage last night
Shoplifters steal millions of dollars worth of merchandise annually
She stole into the room while everyone was sleeping peacefully
The cat stole through the garden hunting for mice

definitions: produce or emit steam or vapor from heat or boiling liquid
cook food using the moist heat of steam rather than boiling water
move or travel using steam power as the means of propulsion
examples: The hot coffee steamed in the cold morning air visibly
The bathroom mirror steams up during hot showers regularly
She prefers to steam vegetables to preserve their nutrients better
The restaurant steams dumplings in traditional bamboo baskets daily
The old locomotive steamed into the station precisely on schedule
Ships steamed across the Atlantic before modern diesel engines

definitions: mentally prepare oneself to do something difficult or unpleasant with determination and courage
examples: She steeled herself before entering the boss's office nervously
Soldiers steel themselves for combat through intensive training programs

definitions: soak something in liquid to extract flavor, soften, or cleanse it thoroughly
examples: Steep the tea leaves in boiling water for five minutes
She steeped the stained fabric in bleach solution overnight

definitions: control the direction of a vehicle or vessel by turning a wheel or using a rudder
guide or direct someone or something toward a particular outcome or course of action
examples: She carefully steered the car through the narrow alley
The captain steered the ship away from the dangerous rocks
The counselor steered students toward appropriate career paths thoughtfully
He tried to steer the conversation away from politics

definitions: originate or arise from a particular source, cause, or root
stop or restrict the flow or progress of something undesirable
examples: Most of our problems stem from poor communication between departments
Her interest in medicine stems from childhood experiences abroad
Emergency measures helped stem the spread of the disease quickly
The government tried to stem inflation through monetary policy

definitions: produce a design or image by applying paint through a cut-out template or pattern
examples: Artists stencil graffiti designs on urban walls using spray paint
She stenciled decorative borders around the nursery walls yesterday

definitions: move by lifting and setting down each foot in turn to advance position
proceed gradually through a series of stages or degrees toward a goal
examples: Please step carefully on the wet floor to avoid slipping
She stepped onto the stage to accept her award
The company plans to step up production next quarter significantly
We need to step through each phase of the project

definitions: view or represent someone or something as a standardized and oversimplified image or idea
examples: Society often stereotypes teenagers as irresponsible and rebellious unfairly
Movies frequently stereotype certain professions in unrealistic ways

definitions: cook food slowly in liquid at a low temperature for extended time
worry or fret anxiously about something for an extended period without resolution
examples: She stewed the beef with vegetables for three hours yesterday
The chef stews tomatoes to make a rich pasta sauce
He stewed about the mistake all weekend without sleeping well
Don't stew over things you cannot change or control

definitions: attach or fasten something to a surface using adhesive or by causing adherence
push a pointed or sharp object into or through something with force
remain in a particular position or place without moving or changing
continue doing something despite difficulties with determination and persistence
examples: Please stick the stamp on the envelope before mailing it
The gum stuck to the bottom of my shoe annoyingly
She stuck the needle through the fabric to begin sewing
He accidentally stuck himself with the thorn while gardening
The car stuck in the mud after the heavy rainfall
That song has stuck in my head all day long
You must stick with your exercise routine to see results
She stuck to her principles despite facing intense criticism

definitions: suppress, restrain, or prevent something from happening or being expressed freely
cause difficulty breathing or feel suffocated especially from heat or lack of air
examples: The government tried to stifle opposition voices before the election
She stifled a yawn during the lengthy board meeting yesterday
The humid weather stifled everyone working outside in the afternoon
Smoke from the fire stifled the trapped victims quickly

definitions: encourage or promote activity, development, or increased function in something or someone
arouse interest, enthusiasm, or excitement in someone about something
examples: Exercise stimulates blood circulation throughout the entire body effectively
The government hopes tax cuts will stimulate economic growth
The teacher used games to stimulate student interest in mathematics
Coffee stimulates mental alertness during long study sessions

definitions: pierce or wound with a sharp pointed organ or stinger as insects do
cause a sharp burning physical pain or sensation on skin or body
cause sharp emotional pain or distress through words or actions
examples: The bee stung her arm when she disturbed the hive
Wasps can sting multiple times unlike honeybees unfortunately
The antiseptic will sting when applied to the open wound
Cold wind stings exposed skin during winter storms harshly
His harsh criticism stung more than she expected emotionally
The betrayal still stings even after all these years

definitions: emit a strong and very unpleasant smell that offends the senses
be extremely bad, unpleasant, or of very poor quality
examples: The garbage stinks after sitting in the heat all day
His gym clothes stink and need immediate washing desperately
This movie really stinks despite its enormous production budget
The whole situation stinks of corruption and dishonesty

definitions: supply an ungenerous or inadequate amount of something needed or desired
examples: Don't stint on safety equipment when building the playground
The restaurant never stints on portion sizes for customers

definitions: demand or specify a requirement as part of an agreement or legal contract
examples: The contract stipulates payment within thirty days of delivery
The judge stipulated that cameras be banned from the courtroom

definitions: mix a liquid or substance by moving a spoon or implement through it
move slightly or begin to move from a stationary position or state
arouse strong feelings or emotions in someone causing them to react
examples: Stir the soup occasionally to prevent it from burning
She stirred sugar into her coffee until it dissolved
The baby stirred in her sleep but didn't wake up
No one stirred from their seats during the performance
The speech stirred patriotic feelings in the entire audience
News of the scandal stirred controversy throughout the community

definitions: make stitches with a needle and thread to join fabric or create designs
repair or close a wound or tear by sewing with needle and thread
examples: She stitched a beautiful pattern on the quilt by hand
The tailor stitched the hem of the dress perfectly straight
The doctor stitched the deep cut with twelve careful sutures
Can you stitch this torn pocket back onto my jacket?
